metadata.titleEn: A new map of permafrost distribution on the Tibetan Plateau (2017)
metadata.description:
Qinghai Tibet Plateau is the largest permafrost area in the world. At present, some permafrost distribution maps have been compiled. However, due to the limited data sources, unclear standards, insufficient verification and lack of high-quality spatial data sets, there is great uncertainty in drawing Permafrost Distribution Maps on TP.
Based on the improved medium resolution imaging spectrometer (MODIS) surface temperature (LSTS) model of 1 km clear sky mod11a2 (Terra MODIS) and myd11a2 (Aqua MODIS) product (reprocessing version 5) in 2003-2012, the data set simulates the distribution of permafrost and generates the permafrost map of Qinghai Tibet Plateau. The map was verified by field observation, soil moisture content and bulk density.
Permafrost attributes mainly include: seasonally frozen ground, permafrost and unfrozen ground.
The data set provides more detailed data of Permafrost Distribution and basic data for the study of permafrost in the Qinghai Tibet Plateau.
metadata.instructions:
File name: the data is stored in grid TIFF format, and the file name is perma_distr_ map.tif
Data reading mode: it can be opened with ArcGIS, QGIS and other remote sensing software to read TIF files

background: Permafrost, defined as ground that remains at or below 0 °C for at least 2 consecutive years (Dobinski, 2011), underlies more than 20 % of the exposed land area in the Northern Hemisphere (Obu et al., 2019) and constitutes an essential component of the Earth system. The Qinghai–Tibet Plateau (QTP), also known as the Earth’s third pole, contains the largest mid- to low-latitude permafrost area in the world. Due to the complex topography and unique plateau climate, permafrost over the QTP is generally of low thermal stability and strongly influenced by complex local factors, such as terrain, vegetation cover, soil properties, and hydrological conditions, which differentiate it from high-latitude permafrost around the Arctic and make it more sensitive to global climate change (Li et al., 2008; Yang et al., 2019; Zhao et al., 2020). In the context of global warming, significant permafrost degradation is occurring on the QTP and has strongly affected hydrological processes (Li et al., 2020), carbon cycling (Mu et al., 2020), and heat exchange processes (Zhao et al., 2020). In addition, hazards related to permafrost degradation threaten construction and infrastructure on the QTP (Wang et al., 2020). Many researchers have studied the complex responses and feedback of permafrost to climate change (Yang et al., 2019), while land surface model-based spatial modeling of permafrost has become an important approach (Ji et al., 2022). Using land surface models, many spatial modeling studies have attempted to project future changes in permafrost (Chang et al., 2018; Debolskiy et al., 2020; Yin et al., 2021), assess the permafrost status under climate change (Koven et al., 2013; Burke et al., 2020), diagnose the contributors to regional permafrost degradation (Zhang et al., 2021a, b; Mekonnen et al., 2021), and project potential feedbacks on the climate system due to permafrost degradation (Zhang et al., 2020; Andresen et al., 2020; Yokohata et al., 2020; Wang et al., 2021). However, evaluating the spatial simulations for the QTP can be challenging due to the limited availability of ground observations, which may not be sufficient to serve as references across the vast spatial modeling domain. Hence, there is a need for an accurate permafrost distribution map that would serve as a reference to validate the results of spatial simulations. The map could be used as a target for the calibration of model parameters and to provide a constraint for future projections to minimize biases resulting from the modeling process. Moreover, an accurate map of permafrost distribution could serve as a fundamental dataset for hydrological, carbon, ecological, and engineering studies in cold regions (Hu et al., 2019a; Li et al., 2020; Song et al., 2020; Mu et al., 2020).
research objective: Based on these criteria, this study aims to produce a permafrost distribution map over the QTP in 2010 through an effective permafrost mapping approach that considers the effects of local factors and utilizes observational data, including remote sensing data and survey-based subregion permafrost maps, as optimization targets and constraints. Our objective is to provide a new reference map for 2010 for permafrost studies on the QTP and to provide a benchmark map for transient simulations of QTP permafrost under climate change.
challenges: Due to the scarcity of ground stations on the QTP, these modeling studies are often hampered by the lack of validation references, calibration targets, and model constraints; however, a high-quality permafrost distribution map would be a good option as a benchmark for spatial simulations. Existing permafrost distribution maps for the QTP can poorly serve this purpose. The accuracy of existing maps is constrained by the limited availability and quality of data used to create them as well as by the inadequacy of mapping approaches. Uncertainties associated with mapping approaches also negatively impact the accuracy of existing permafrost maps. Common statistical learning methods for permafrost mapping (Wang et al., 2019c; Ni et al., 2021) heavily rely on in situ observations as a training dataset. Therefore, they are often compromised when ground observations are unevenly distributed and have different observation periods, as is the case for the QTP. Meanwhile, the lack of accurate soil properties, fine-tuned parameterization schemes, and high-resolution forcing data on the QTP severely challenged the applications of land surface models in mapping permafrost (Wu et al., 2018). These physically explicit models were often calibrated and validated at a point scale, leading to unpredictable uncertainties when extended to a large region with more variability and, thus, more complex conditions (Qin et al., 2017; Wu et al., 2018).
methods: In this study, we created a new permafrost distribution map for the QTP in 2010 using a novel permafrost mapping approach with satellite-derived ground surface thawing and freezing indices as inputs and survey-based subregion permafrost maps as constraints. We applied the FROSTNUM/COP mapping method developed by Hu et al. (2020) to map the distribution of permafrost on the QTP. The general process of this method and the improvements that we made in this study are outlined in Fig. 2. It is based on the extended ground surface frost number (FROSTNUM) model fed by satellite temperature data (Fig. 2a, b), and it requires permafrost distribution maps for subregions as optimization constraints. This method accounts for local factors through a model parameter E, whose values were optimally determined for all spatial units following a procedure of spatial clustering (Fig. 2c), parametric optimization (Fig. 2d), and decision tree (Fig. 2c). The optimization procedure in the original FROSTNUM/COP method uses Cohen’s kappa coefficient (Cohen, 1960) as an objective function, which measures the agreement of frozen-soil-type classification between the simulated map and survey-based subregion maps. In this study, we specially reduced the equifinality problem by modifying the objective function to additionally include a metric that guarantees boundary consistency and by introducing an ensemble simulation of 1000 runs of parametric optimization. DDF and DDT were calculated based on the MOD11A1 and MYD11A1 Level 3 products (Version 6). Despite many all-weather LST products (Zhang et al., 2021; Xu and Cheng, 2021), we chose a stepwise interpolation approach based on the solar–cloud–satellite geometry (SCSG) effect (Chen et al., 2023) to interpolate the data-gap regions in the MODIS LST data. Due to the buffering effect of seasonal snow cover and vegetation, thermal offsets often exist between satellite-derived LST values and GST values. Therefore, for the DDF values, we simply calculated the sum of negative degree-days of mean daily LST from four instantaneous LST observations, ignoring the effects of snow cover. To this end, we developed a multilinear regression model where GST is a function of independent variables including the raw LST, NDVI, and latitude at weather stations (Huang et al., 2020). The correction was repeated over 23 time intervals a year, and the annual DDT was the aggregate of all these corrected positive degree-days. We followed the method developed by Hu et al. (2020) to spatially group the soils of five subregions into soil clusters. The particle swarm optimization (PSO) algorithm (Wang et al., 2018) was used to find the optimal value of E associated with each soil cluster.
dataset: The dataset is available from the repository hosted on Figshare (Cao et al., 2022): https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.19642362.
findings: This new map showed a total permafrost area of about 1.086 × 10^6 km^2 (41.2 % of the QTP area) and seasonally frozen ground of about 1.447 × 10^6 km^2 (54.9 %) in 2010, excluding glaciers and lakes. Validations using survey-based subregion permafrost maps (κ=0.74) and borehole records (overall accuracy=0.85 and κ=0.43) showed a higher accuracy of this map compared with two other recent maps. Inspection of regions with obvious distinctions between the maps affirms that the permafrost distribution on this map is more realistic than that on the Zou et al. (2017) map. Given the demonstrated excellent accuracy, this map can serve as a benchmark map for constraining/validating land surface simulations on the QTP and as a historical reference for projecting future permafrost changes on the QTP in the context of global warming.

Definition.Question: What is a permafrost distribution map and why is it important for studies on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Definition.Answer: A permafrost distribution map is a detailed representation of permafrost areas, showing where permafrost exists and does not exist. It is important for studies on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau (QTP) because it serves as a reference to validate spatial simulation results, helps calibrate model parameters, and provides a constraint for future projections to minimize modeling biases. This map is also crucial as a fundamental dataset for hydrological, carbon, ecological, and engineering studies in cold regions.

Definition.Question: What is the FROSTNUM/COP mapping method used in permafrost studies?
Definition.Answer: The FROSTNUM/COP mapping method is a novel approach used to map the distribution of permafrost. It is based on the extended ground surface frost number (FROSTNUM) model, which uses satellite-derived ground surface thawing and freezing indices as inputs and survey-based subregion permafrost maps as constraints. This method accounts for local factors and involves spatial clustering, parametric optimization, and decision trees to optimize permafrost distribution mapping.

Definition.Question: What are the challenges associated with permafrost mapping on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Definition.Answer: Challenges associated with permafrost mapping on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau include the scarcity of ground stations, which limits validation references and calibration targets. Existing maps often suffer from inaccuracies due to limited and poor-quality data, inadequate mapping approaches, and uncertainties associated with these methods. Additionally, common statistical learning methods heavily rely on in situ observations that are unevenly distributed and have different observation periods, creating further complications.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in challenges faced by statistical learning methods relying on in situ observations versus land surface models in mapping permafrost on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Comparison.Answer: Statistical learning methods that rely on in situ observations face challenges due to uneven distribution and varying observation periods of ground data. This can compromise the reliability of these methods across the vast and diverse Qinghai-Tibet Plateau. Land surface models, on the other hand, encounter difficulties due to the lack of accurate soil properties, fine-tuned parameterization schemes, and high-resolution forcing data. These models are often calibrated at a point scale, which can lead to uncertainties when applied over larger, more variable regions.

Interpretation.Question: What factors could influence the accuracy of permafrost distribution models when using satellite-derived data for mapping, and how might these factors be addressed in data collection methods?
Interpretation.Answer: The accuracy of permafrost distribution models could be influenced by factors such as terrain, vegetation cover, soil properties, and hydrological conditions. These factors can be addressed by incorporating diverse observational data, optimizing model parameters for local conditions, and using high-resolution remote sensing data to capture spatial variability.

Interpretation.Question: How might the scarcity of ground-based observations on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau impact the reliability of permafrost mapping, and what strategies could be employed to mitigate these challenges in data collection?
Interpretation.Answer: The scarcity of ground-based observations can limit validation references and model constraints, impacting reliability. Strategies to mitigate these challenges include using satellite data as substitutes, applying novel mapping approaches that incorporate local factors, and validating with survey-based maps and borehole records to improve accuracy.

Interpretation.Question: What methodological innovations could enhance the calibration of permafrost distribution maps in the context of climate change projections, and how might these be integrated into existing datasets?
Interpretation.Answer: Methodological innovations such as using extended ground surface frost number models, ensemble simulations of parametric optimizations, and incorporating metrics for boundary consistency can enhance calibration. Integrating these innovations involves refining satellite data interpolation methods and developing models that account for thermal offsets due to seasonal snow cover and vegetation.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is there a need for a high-quality permafrost distribution map to validate spatial simulations on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: A high-quality permafrost distribution map is needed due to the scarcity of ground observations, which are insufficient to serve as references across the vast spatial modeling domain. Such a map would provide a benchmark for spatial simulations, serve as a calibration target to minimize modeling biases, and act as a fundamental dataset for hydrological, carbon, ecological, and engineering studies in cold regions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the uncertainties in the current permafrost mapping approaches for the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Uncertainties in current mapping approaches are caused by common statistical learning methods that heavily rely on in situ observations, which are often unevenly distributed. The lack of accurate soil properties, fine-tuned parameterization schemes, and high-resolution forcing data also challenges the applications of land surface models, leading to unpredictable uncertainties when extended to large regions with complex conditions.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of using satellite-derived ground surface thawing and freezing indices in permafrost mapping over traditional ground-based observations?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using satellite-derived indices allows for more comprehensive spatial coverage and can serve as an input for novel permafrost mapping approaches, which helps address the scarcity and uneven distribution of ground stations. This method can support creating a high-quality permafrost distribution map that provides a reliable benchmark for spatial simulations and helps improve the accuracy of permafrost maps.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it necessary to address the challenges of using common statistical learning methods for permafrost mapping in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: It is necessary because the scarcity and uneven distribution of ground observations, along with different observation periods, compromise the effectiveness of statistical learning methods. Addressing these challenges allows for more accurate permafrost mapping by improving validation references, calibration targets, and model constraints, which are essential for reliable spatial simulations and high-resolution permafrost distribution maps.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures can be used to improve the accuracy of permafrost distribution maps over the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau using remote sensing data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: A novel permafrost mapping approach can be utilized, which uses satellite-derived ground surface thawing and freezing indices as inputs and incorporates survey-based subregion permafrost maps as constraints. The FROSTNUM/COP mapping method can be applied, optimizing the model parameters through spatial clustering, parametric optimization, and decision tree processes.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can remote sensing data be processed to address data gaps when mapping permafrost areas?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Data gaps in MODIS LST data can be interpolated using a stepwise approach based on the solar–cloud–satellite geometry (SCSG) effect. This helps to ensure continuity in the temperature data used for permafrost mapping, taking into consideration thermal offsets due to seasonal snow cover and vegetation.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What steps are involved in validating a new permafrost distribution map to ensure its reliability?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Validation involves comparing the new map with survey-based subregion permafrost maps and borehole records. The accuracy is typically assessed using metrics such as Cohen's kappa coefficient and overall accuracy. This process helps ensure that the map can serve as a benchmark for spatial simulations and future projections.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements enable the creation of accurate permafrost distribution maps for the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: The use of improved middle-resolution imaging spectroradiometer (MODIS) land surface temperature (LST) data and the application of models like the FROSTNUM/COP mapping approach allow for more accurate permafrost distribution maps by accounting for local factors and utilizing satellite-derived data.

Enablement.Question: How do specific data collection methods contribute to the validation of permafrost distribution maps over the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: Data collection methods such as field observations, soil moisture, and bulk density surveys, along with subregion permafrost maps, contribute to the validation process by providing essential reference data to assess and improve the accuracy of permafrost distribution maps.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or data sources enable the reduction of uncertainties in mapping permafrost on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of satellite-derived thawing and freezing indices, along with survey-based subregion maps, helps reduce uncertainties by providing optimization targets and constraints, which improve the mapping accuracy and mitigate the challenges posed by uneven ground observation distributions.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be significant challenges in acquiring accurate permafrost distribution data on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Expectation.Answer: Due to the complex topography and unique plateau climate, permafrost over the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau is generally of low thermal stability and strongly influenced by local factors such as terrain, vegetation cover, soil properties, and hydrological conditions. Additionally, the scarcity of ground stations makes it difficult to validate modeling studies, leading to uncertainties in existing permafrost distribution maps.

Expectation.Question: Why might existing permafrost maps be insufficient for validating spatial simulations of permafrost on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Expectation.Answer: Existing permafrost maps for the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau often suffer from inaccuracies due to limited availability and quality of data, inadequacy of mapping approaches, and uneven distribution of ground observations. These factors result in poor validation references, calibration targets, and model constraints necessary for accurate spatial simulations.

Judgmental.Question: How do researchers evaluate the effectiveness of satellite-derived indices in mapping permafrost distribution on complex terrains like the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Judgmental.Answer: Researchers utilize satellite-derived ground surface thawing and freezing indices as inputs, combined with survey-based subregion permafrost maps as constraints, to map permafrost distribution. They apply novel mapping methods like the FROSTNUM/COP method, which optimizes spatial clustering and utilizes decision trees to account for local factors, thereby improving the accuracy of permafrost mapping in complex terrains.

Judgmental.Question: What are the perceived challenges in using land surface models for mapping permafrost, and how might these be mitigated?
Judgmental.Answer: Challenges include the scarcity of ground observations for validation, the inadequacy of existing permafrost maps, and uncertainties in mapping approaches. These challenges might be mitigated by developing high-quality permafrost distribution maps that serve as benchmarks, refining parameterization schemes, and utilizing high-resolution forcing data to enhance model applications across varied and complex conditions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the challenges associated with using common statistical learning methods for permafrost mapping in regions with limited ground observations.
Request/Directive.Answer: Common statistical learning methods for permafrost mapping face challenges due to reliance on unevenly distributed ground observations. In regions like the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau, where observation periods and spatial distribution vary, these methods are compromised. The lack of accurate soil properties and high-resolution data further challenges the use of these models, leading to unpredictable uncertainties when extended to larger regions with complex conditions.
